field.name: summary
field.value: Kernel.GetHandlers(Type) does not consider generic handlers when satisfying the type

field.name: description
field.value:
Basically this is a reaction to Ayende's recent fix to support smart chaining decorators. This feature only works when the service types of the decorators are exactly the same (generic or not) It would be consistent and desirable to be able to use generic components when trying to satisify component dependencies and simplify the configuration.
e.g. If I have the following registrations
<component id="active.record.repository" service="Rhino.Commons.IRepository`1, Rhino.Commons" type="Rhino.Commons.ARRepository`1, Rhino.Commons "> </component>
<component id="smart.canister.repository" service="Rhino.Commons.IRepository`1[[EC.DomainModel.Canister, EC.DomainModel]], Rhino.Commons" type=" EC.Application.JVM.SmartCanisterRepositoryDecorator, EC.Application"> </component>
And the EC.Application.JVM.SmartCanisterRepositoryDecorator component has a constructor that expects an IRepository<Canister>, the kernel does not recognize that the "active.record.repository" can satisfy the dependency.
So one of the questions is how do we properly consider IHandler equivelance? Should we add and bool IHandler.Implies(Type) or something like that to determine when a give handler can satisfy a particular type?
Any ideas are welcome.
